tests.key_findings: Profound SNHL Right ear. Left ear mild-to-moderate HF SNHL.

history.present_illness: Patient experienced increased difficulty communicating on the telephone and was terrified she was losing hearing in her left ear. Initial follow-up with local ENT (Dr. 1) was dismissive. After consultation between Dr. 1 and Dr. 2, patient was referred to Dr. 3, an otologist with expertise in autoimmune inner ear disease (AIED). Diagnosis of AIED was established through process of elimination based on: bilateral progressive/fluctuating SNHL, history of other autoimmune manifestations (canker sores, episcleritis, shortness of breath), and a 10+ year history of elevated ESR.
history.otologic_history: Right ear anacusic since mid-1985. Left ear now showing fluctuation, noted approximately 1 month after flying.
history.medical_psych_history: Canker sores since college. Episcleritis in both eyes treated with monthly steroid injections. Shortness of breath despite being physically active. Elevated ESR discovered in early 40s during routine physical.
history.prior_management: CT scan in August 1985 was negative. Dr. 2 had speculated viral infection or hydrops. CROS aid evaluation recommended but not yet pursued.

tests.name: Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)
tests.key_findings: Abnormally elevated, consistent with active inflammatory or autoimmune process.

management.medical_treatment: Aggressive immunosuppressive therapy initiated: 2 weeks of IV cyclophosphamide (Cytoxan) 30 minutes/day, followed by 3 months of oral prednisone and immunosuppressants.
management.rationale: Goal was to halt progression of hearing loss in the left ear.

history.present_illness: Over the next 1.5 years, Left ear began to fluctuate and decline. Right ear remained dead. Vertigo subsided but imbalance persisted.
history.otologic_history: Right ear anacusis; Left ear now fluctuating SNHL.
history.medical_psych_history: Additional autoimmune manifestations noted over time.
history.prior_management: Evaluated by multiple ENTs; referred to otologist specializing in AIED.

history.present_illness: Immunosuppressive therapy (Cytoxan and prednisone) started; Left ear improved somewhat.
history.otologic_history: Right ear dead. Left ear partially recovered after treatment.
history.prior_management: Started immunosuppressive therapy after AIED diagnosis.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear showed partial improvement in thresholds after immunosuppressive treatment.

overall_audiologic_summary: Elderly female with sudden profound Right SNHL progressing to anacusic ear and subsequent fluctuating/progressive Left SNHL. Workup ultimately led to diagnosis of autoimmune inner ear disease (AIED) by exclusion, supported by systemic autoimmune features and markedly elevated ESR. CT scan negative. ENG showed Right peripheral vestibular deficit. Aggressive immunosuppressive therapy (Cytoxan + prednisone) partially stabilized/improved Left ear hearing.
counseling_points: Explain the diagnosis of AIED and that it is often made by exclusion.
Discuss importance of early treatment to preserve remaining hearing in the better ear.
Review realistic expectations for hearing rehabilitation given Right ear anacusic and Left ear progressive SNHL.
Provide support for balance/vestibular compensation strategies.
notes_for_actor: You are a very active minister and highly motivated to communicate.
You are distressed by the sudden loss in your right ear and fearful about losing hearing in the left.
You use visual cues and may need assistance for balance.
